titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accession 2017:050
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accession 2017:050 FA1304
titlestmt.author: Katie Martin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-22 03:03:26 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accession 2017:050

physdesc.extent: 113 boxes - 97 letter document containers, 14 legal document containers, 1 Paige box, and 1 oversize document box (16.5x12.5)

did.langmaterial: English; Publications related to international work typically include native language and English translations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ford Foundation records, Publications (Non-Grant Related), Accession 2017:050 consists of pamphlets, reprints, brochures, reports, conference papers, and other publications by the Ford Foundation or by authors involved in Ford Foundation projects.

The subject areas of these publications reflect the Ford Foundation's areas of interest, including philanthropy, higher education, public education, the arts and humanities, equal opportunity, women's programs, housing, urban and local programs, working-class concerns, communications and journalism, administration of justice, resources and the environment, the energy policy project, and international programs related to agriculture, education, international studies, and population.

The collection also houses working publication files, including publication design files, correspondence and memoranda, distribution files, and press materials. These files can be identified by a title that will include "Job" and a series of numbers followed by the name of the publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged as received from the Ford Foundation in 2017. Boxes 110-113 contain duplicate copies of various publications. They are listed intellectually with the first recorded instance of the publication in the finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas.

During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2017 by the Ford Foundation and ingested by RAC as Accession 2017:050.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Special format items have been separated from the body of the collection and assigned a unique separation number, as noted. Requests to access open special formats should reference the unique separation number.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A Ford Foundation Report - In 1974, when the Ford Foundation first published a report on its activities related to opportunities for women titled That 51 Per Cent, the female proportion of the United States population was 51.05 per cent. At the writing of this new report, in 1978, the proportion had increased slightly, to 51.25 per cent, but the increase in strength of the women's movement was substantially greater.
